title: Front Brake Caliper - Installation

body.body: Temporarily fit the calipers to the front forks.
Connect the brake hoses to the calipers incorporating new sealing washers on each side of the hose connections.
The brake hose is correctly positioned when the crimped ends of the brake caliper and hose union are visually aligned to 38.5°+/- 5°.
Make sure when fitted, the brake hose is routed so that it does not interfere with the front forks or radiator when turning the steering from lock to lock.
Make sure the brake hoses are positioned as shown below and tighten the union bolt to
Do not allow the calipers to hang on the brake hoses as this may damage the hoses and could lead to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Thoroughly clean the threaded fixing holes for the front fork brake caliper fixings.
Thoroughly clean the threaded part of the brake caliper fixings and smear the first four threads with a proprietary copper based grease.
Position the brake caliper over the disc.

Secure the brake caliper with the fixings and tighten sufficiently to bring the caliper into contact with its mounting points, while allowing a small amount of lateral movement. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
Before tightening, the brake caliper should be positioned such that it is aligned as centrally as possible over the brake disc.
Visually check the clearances between the caliper body and brake disc in the four locations shown below.
Slide the caliper body inwards or outwards against its fixings as required to achieve the most equal clearances possible on either side of the brake disc.
Holding the caliper in position against its mounting fixings, tighten the fixings to
When the brake caliper is fitted, there must be a minimum gap of 0.3 mm between the caliper and brake disc.
Using feeler gauges, measure the gap between the front brake caliper and the brake disc at the four measurement points shown in the following illustration. Minimum gap to be 0.3 mm.
If necessary, loosen the caliper bolts and adjust the caliper alignment to achieve the minimum gap of 0.3 mm on all four measurement points. Re-tighten the bolts to
Move the handlebars to left and right full lock while checking that the brake hose, clutch cable and electrical harnesses do not bind or that the steering feels tight or difficult to turn.
A hose, cable or harness that binds, or steering that is tight/difficult to turn will restrict the steering and may cause loss of control and an accident.

Check for correct operation of the front brake, clutch and twist grip. Check that the brake hose, clutch cable and electrical harnesses do not bind or restrict the steering when the handlebars are turned from lock-to-lock.
